overall_score_comment: Like a true crime podcast hosted by your most dramatic friend — equal parts entertaining and concerning.
the_roast:
Look, I appreciate the self-awareness of chanting 'I'm so mature' while literally plotting a double homicide in your basement. That's like wearing a 'World's Best Driver' t-shirt while running a red light. The therapist is doing GREAT work here, really earning that copay when you respond to 'there's other men' with 'cool story, but I'm gonna need bail money.'

The farmer's market detail is chef's kiss levels of petty. Not 'he took her somewhere nice' — no, it's specifically the FARMER'S MARKET with a PERFECT PEACH. You're about to commit felonies and you're still mad about organic produce. That's the kind of specific jealousy that belongs in a group chat, not a murder plan. And can we talk about how you jumped from 'saw him shopping for fruit' to 'planning home invasion' with ZERO steps in between? That's not character development, that's a teleportation spell fueled by pure spite.

The real tragedy is the disclaimer 'I did it all on no drugs / I did all of this sober' — like you're worried people might think SUBSTANCES were the problem here. Ma'am, the call is coming from inside the house. You're out here writing confession letters set to a beat and calling them text messages that are 'evidence.' At least you're documenting your own crimes efficiently. True crime podcasters will thank you for making their jobs easier.

cliche_counter.cliche: If I can't have you, no one will
cliche_counter.quip: The rallying cry of every Lifetime movie villain ever — originality took a restraining order out on this line

cliche_counter.cliche: Rather be in jail/Hell than alone
cliche_counter.quip: Prison food and eternal damnation > Tinder apparently, which honestly tracks with modern dating
Nothing says 'love language' quite like premeditated murder — maybe lead with flowers next time?

cliche_counter.cliche: I did it all for love
cliche_counter.quip: Every true crime documentary defendant's opening statement, usually followed by a gavel sound

lyrical_crime_highlights.line: You was at the farmer's market with your perfect peach
lyrical_crime_highlights.sentence: Mandatory anger management classes at Whole Foods

lyrical_crime_highlights.line: This text gon' be evidence, this text is evidence
lyrical_crime_highlights.sentence: Retake Criminology 101 and never watch Law & Order again

lyrical_crime_highlights.line: Now I'm in the basement plannin' home invasion
lyrical_crime_highlights.sentence: Banned from HGTV for turning home improvement into home endangerment

lyrical_crime_highlights.line: I'm so mature, I'm so mature, I'm so mature
lyrical_crime_highlights.crime: Protesting way too much while planning felonies
lyrical_crime_highlights.sentence: Required to say 'I'm so immature' three times in a mirror like Bloody Mary

hidden_meanings: Clearly this is a brilliant metaphor about how capitalism's farmer's markets represent the gentrification of love, where only those who can afford perfect organic peaches deserve happiness. The 'basement' symbolizes descending into late-stage relationship entropy, and 'jail' is actually freedom from society's oppressive expectation that we be normal about breakups. Or maybe it's just about wanting to commit crimes. Hard to say.
final_verdict: A bop that doubles as a full confession — catchy enough to sing along to, concerning enough to submit as evidence. Your Honor, the defense rests, but apparently SZA never will.
title: Kill Bill
